p: Inflammation has been reported to happen via multiple mechanisms and by varying mediators resulting in a wide variety of deleterious effects including necrosis, degeneration and different types of exudation ( Medzhitov, 2008). However, analgesic drugs are used to manage the pain, inflammation and categorized as opioids (morphine, fentanyl), NSAIDs and some newer approaches (gabapentin, carbamazepine, ketamine). Besides, glucocorticoids exert response by binding with receptors resulting in increased transcription of anti-inflammatory proteins (e.g., IL-1 antagonist) along with inhibition of activated transcription factors (e.g., NF-ÎºB) ( Barnes, 1998). NSAIDs also inhibit cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2) which are responsible for the biosynthesis of various inflammatory mediators. Though various NSAIDs are commercially available, they exhibit few major side effects including GI ulceration, liver toxicity, kidney disease etc. after prolonged uses ( Sostres et al., 2010). Thus, new phytochemicals may be investigated to establish better alternatives ( Liu, 2007).
